title: Publications
text:
Monograph

The Craft of Indo-Arabic Numerals: How Practical Arithmetic Shaped Commerce and Mathematics in Western Europe, 1200-1600. Monograph contracted, peer reviewed, and accepted for publication with Harvard University Press. Expected publication: spring 2026.



Peer-reviewed papers

Algebra in Transit in Late Medieval and Early Modern Europe, Physis (2025), 60 (1), 1-30.
The spread of Hindu-Arabic numerals among practitioners in Italy and England (13th-16th c.): two moments of a European innovation cycle? Datini Studies in Economic History (2023), 259-287.
Elaboration and diffusion of useful knowledge in the long run: the case of European practical arithmetic (13th-16th centuries), Rivista di Storia Economica (2022), 1, 57-84.
Figuring Out: the Spread of Hindu-Arabic Numerals in the European Tradition of Practical Mathematics (13th-16th centuries), Nuncius,(2021), 36 (1), 1-44.
Una scienza per la rinascita. Note su Paolo dell’Abaco e la matematica abacistica fiorentina, Rinascimento (2019), 59.



Working papers

(with M. Iori and A. Mina) ‘A Numerical Revolution: The Diffusion of Practical Mathematics and the Growth of Pre-Modern European Economies’, SSRN Working Paper and LEM Working Paper, 2022.



(with T. Morel) ‘Text and practices: situating mathematics in practical arithmetic manuals. Evidence from German and Italian cases (14th-16th c.)’, in R. Wagner and S. Babu (eds.), Normative Texts and Occupational Practices, Boston Studies in the Philosophy and History of Science, Cham: Springer. Peer reviewed and accepted: forthcoming.
(with S. Locatelli) ‘Dalla teoria alla prassi della matematica: libri d’abaco e pratiche di mercatura nel tardo medioevo’, Studi di Storia Medioevale e Diplomatica. Peer reviewed and accepted: forthcoming.
‘The Values of Numbers: The Roots of European Algebra in Late Medieval Commercial Capitalism’.



Book Chapters

Un rinascimento dal basso: l’aritmetica mercantile e la sua epistemologia pratica, in Lo sguardo del lupo. Arte, matematica e filosofia nell’umanesimo del Quadrivio, Bologna: Pendragon (2024), 43-72.

Guest editor (with Francesco Brusori) for a Special Issue of Galilaeana – Studies in Renaissance and Early Modern Science. Theme: “Knowledge in Use. Practices and Practitioners in the Renaissance and Early Modern Period (14th-17th centuries)”. Expected publication: October 2026.

title: Raffaele Danna
text:
I am an historian working on economic history and the history of science. I believe that exploring the interconnections of technical, scientific, and economic processes is essential to understand the complexity of historical change.
I am a researcher at the Sant’Anna School of Advanced Studies in Pisa. I hold a PhD in History from the University of Cambridge and I have been a Max Weber Fellow at the European University Institute.
